For as long as anyone in the area could remember, North Crab Lake seemed lost in time - clear as glass and surrounded by trees.
You could reach it by canoe or by hiking along an overgrown logging road, up rocky hills and down into soggy valleys blanketed with ferns.
All that changed last spring, when a developer started building the new road.
It slices deep into the hills and rises high above the valleys.
In places, its reddish-brown banks are 100-feet wide.
It looks like a highway made of dirt.
This summer, near the end of the road, there was a confrontation.
On one side, there were some local landowners.
On the other, representatives for the developer.
The neighbors suspected the road violated federal laws that protect wetlands.
For months, they've been attending meetings and calling local and state officials to ask someone to look into the matter.
They'd gotten nowhere.
Then they heard that these same officials had come to North Crab Lake to look at the road.
So they set off - a half dozen gray-haired retirees, determined to make their case.
Karen Tobiren(ph) paused along the way to point to things that worried her, including places where rainwater had scalloped the road's edges and carried big chunks of it into the wetland below.

There are no silt fences along here, and you can see some of the silt already down on the side of the road right here, all the way the bottom, moving towards the Presque Isle River - which is between North Crab and Armor Lake.
Her neighbor, Bill Comstock(ph), carried a map.
It showed three of the lots the developer had just put up for sale.
The whole development of these three lots is primarily on wetland.
In a sunny clearing, Comstock and his neighbors spotted the officials.
They were talking with Adam Johnson, a consultant to the developer.
He was not pleased to see them.
As of right now, you're on private property.
Right now.
So if you wouldn't mind just going back by that line over there, that's what we're suggesting to do by everybody...
Are government officials, are they saying, yeah, we don't want these people here?
It doesn't matter what they want.
Doesn't matter what the government officials want?
No. The property owners want everybody over there.
Johnson ultimately relented.
The neighbors got a few minutes to have their say.
It did not go well for them.
I cannot believe there is such a ruckus over this.
Jack Harrison, a member of the Presque Isle Town Board, said wetlands aren't the town's responsibility.
Ben Peck(ph), who built the road, said he followed the rules.
The county has been here.
There are no issues.
The town has been here - there are no issues.
The town board and the town zoning committee approved the lots and approved the subdivision.
If you don't like what was done, then the ordinances need to be changed.
You can't stop the development.
Even a state official - Jane Wade from the Department of Natural Resources - said as far as she could tell, the road was fine.
This was an existing road, and you can fill in an existing road.
